metadata.title: Modal Verbs - Helping Verbs with Special Powers
metadata.subject: English - Grammar

scenes.title: Meet the Modal Verbs
scenes.narration_text: Hello friends! Today we'll learn about Modal Verbs, also called helping verbs. They are special words that help other verbs and give them different meanings. The main modal verbs are: may, should, can, must, need to, and used to. Let's explore their superpowers!
scenes.visual_prompt: Six superhero characters, each wearing a cape with a modal verb: MAY, SHOULD, CAN, MUST, NEED TO, USED TO. They stand in a heroic pose.

scenes.title: MAY - Making Suggestions
scenes.narration_text: First, meet MAY! We use 'may' to make polite suggestions. For example: You may share your lunch with your friend. You may borrow my book. It's a gentle way to give permission or make a suggestion!
scenes.visual_prompt: Two children at lunch table. One child saying 'You may share my sandwich!' with a friendly smile. Speech bubble shows 'MAY = Suggestion'.

scenes.title: SHOULD - Giving Advice
scenes.narration_text: Next is SHOULD! We use 'should' to give advice or say what's the right thing to do. Listen: You should brush your teeth twice a day. You should be kind to animals. It's like giving friendly advice!
scenes.visual_prompt: A caring teacher or parent figure giving advice to a child. Speech bubbles: 'You should eat healthy food', 'You should study regularly'. Label: 'SHOULD = Advice'.

scenes.title: CAN - Showing Ability
scenes.narration_text: Here comes CAN! We use 'can' to show what we're able to do. For example: I can swim. She can speak three languages. He can ride a bicycle. It shows our abilities and skills!
scenes.visual_prompt: Three panels showing abilities: 1) Child swimming (I can swim), 2) Girl with language flags (She can speak), 3) Boy on bicycle (He can ride). Label: 'CAN = Ability'.

scenes.title: MUST - Showing Compulsion
scenes.narration_text: Now meet MUST! This is the strongest modal verb. We use 'must' when something is very important and has to be done. Example: You must wear a helmet while cycling. You must complete your homework. It's not a choice - it's necessary!
scenes.visual_prompt: Important safety signs: Child wearing helmet on bike, student doing homework. Red 'MUST' stamps. Label: 'MUST = Compulsion (Very Important!)'.

scenes.title: NEED TO and USED TO
scenes.narration_text: Finally, NEED TO shows necessity - I need to study for my test. And USED TO shows past habits - I used to play with toys when I was little. Now you know all the modal verbs and their special powers!
scenes.visual_prompt: Two scenes: 1) Student studying with books (need to = necessity), 2) Old photo of child with toys (used to = past habit). Summary of all 6 modals at bottom.
